definition: Xu Fu (3rd century BC), Qin dynasty court necromancer
slowly/gently
surname Xu
good fortune/happiness/luck
surname Fu/abbr. for Fujian province 福建省[Fu2 jian4 sheng3]

sentences.english: But that square private, would be legendary Xu Fu?
sentences.chinese: 而那個方士，便是傳說中的徐福？

sentences.english: By contrast, Hsu Fu Chi commands about a 5.5% share of China's confectionary market.
sentences.chinese: 相比之下，徐福記只佔中國糖果市場的5%。
淵源你看，那位就是徐福。

sentences.english: City Xu Fuzhen, known as the Xu Xiang County, the hometown of Xu Fu for the alchemist.
sentences.chinese: 龍口徐福鎮，古稱徐鄉縣，爲秦朝方士徐福故里。

sentences.english: City Xu Fuzhen, known as the Xu Xiang County, the hometown of Xu Fu for the alchemist.
sentences.chinese: 龍口徐福鎮，古稱徐鄉縣，爲秦朝方士徐福故里。

sentences.english: Will the Chinese government allow Nestlé to buy Hsu Fu Chi?
sentences.chinese: 中國政府會允許雀巢收購徐福記嗎？

sentences.english: The most successful swindler in the history is Xu Fu.
sentences.chinese: 這世上最牛的騙子當屬徐福了。

sentences.english: Life in Japan's Xu Fu's for generations descendants, must similarly so.
sentences.chinese: 生活在日本的徐福的世世代代子孫，也應當同樣如此。

definition: alchemist/necromancer
Qin Shihuang (259-210 BC), the first emperor
legendary magic potion of immortals/panacea/fig. wonder solution to a problem
Yingzhou, easternmost of three fabled islands in Eastern sea, home of immortals and source of elixir of immortality

Wei Lao (c. 450 BC, dates of birth and death unknown), advisor to the first Qin emperor Qin Shihuang 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2], possible author of the Wei Liaozi 尉繚子|尉缭子[Wei4 Liao2 zi5] text on military strategy
Peng Zu (legendary figure of Taoism who lived 800 years)
immortality
the Yellow Emperor, mythological emperor of China, reigned c. 2697-2597 BC
Han Fei, also known as Han Feizi 韓非子|韩非子[Han2 Fei1 zi3] (c. 280-233 BC), Legalist philosopher of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
see Jiang Ziya 姜子牙[Jiang1 Zi3 ya2]
the First Emperor 259-210 BC
Huang Shigong, also known as Xia Huanggong 夏黃公|夏黄公[Xia4 Huang2 gong1] (dates of birth and death uncertain), Daoist hermit of the Qin Dynasty 秦代[Qin2 dai4] and purported author
Prince Dan of Yan (-226 BC), commissioned the attempted assassination of King Ying Zheng of Qin 秦嬴政 (later the First Emperor 秦始皇) by Jing Ke 荆轲 in 227 BC
Jianzhen or Ganjin (688-763), Tang Buddhist monk, who crossed to Japan after several unsuccessful attempts, influential in Japanese Buddhism
Prince Dan of Yan (-226 BC), commissioned the attempted assassination of King Ying Zheng of Qin 秦嬴政 (later the First Emperor 秦始皇) by Jing Ke 荆轲 in 227 BC
Zhang Yi (-309 BC), political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
